Key Findings

  • A department listed without any identifying name accounts for £137,542,805.16—representing 38.7% of Burnley Borough Council's total £355,218,405.44 expenditure across the five-year period from 2021/22 to 2025/26.
  • Planning & Transportation is the highest identified spending area at £58,369,593.44 (16.4% of total spend), followed by Environmental Services at £35,712,722.46 (10.1%).
  • Legal & Democratic services consume £35,264,028.11—just £448,694.35 less than the entire Environmental Services budget, despite being an administrative function rather than a front-line service.
  • Leisure & Culture receives the smallest departmental allocation at £7,941,880.31 (2.2%), which is £2,095,477.73 less than the Chief Executive & Corporate budget.
  • The top three departmental allocations combined account for 65.2% of the council's entire budget, leaving the remaining seven categories to share just 34.8% of resources.

The £137 Million Question

When Burnley Borough Council published its spending records under the Local Government Transparency Code, one entry stood out for its absence rather than its presence. A departmental allocation of £137,542,805.16—representing more than 38 pence of every pound spent by the council—appears with no name, no description, and no identifying label.

This unlabelled category, spread across five financial years from 2021/22 to 2025/26, exceeds the combined budgets of Planning & Transportation, Environmental Services, and Legal & Democratic services. For context, this single anonymous line item costs taxpayers more than the next three largest departments put together. In an era of local government transparency, the failure to identify where over one-third of the council's £355.2 million total expenditure flows represents a significant accountability gap.

Departmental Breakdown: Following the Money

The council's spending reveals stark disparities between service areas. While some departments command nine-figure sums, others operate on fractions of that amount. The following table presents the complete allocation of Burnley's budget across nine departmental categories:

Department/Service Area Total Spend (£) Percentage of Budget
[Unnamed Department] 137,542,805.16 38.7%
Planning & Transportation 58,369,593.44 16.4%
Environmental Services 35,712,722.46 10.1%
Legal & Democratic 35,264,028.11 9.9%
Regeneration & Housing 26,488,248.71 7.5%
Other 23,757,926.36 6.7%
Resources & Finance 20,103,842.85 5.7%
Chief Executive & Corporate 10,037,358.04 2.8%
Leisure & Culture 7,941,880.31 2.2%

Administrative Weight vs Public Services

Perhaps the most striking comparison emerges between the council's administrative machinery and its front-line services. Legal & Democratic services—encompassing governance, elections, and committee administration—cost £35,264,028.11, consuming 9.9% of the total budget. This figure sits just £448,694.35 below the £35,712,722.46 allocated to Environmental Services, which covers waste collection, street cleaning, and pollution control.

Similarly, the Chief Executive & Corporate function—covering senior leadership, communications, and corporate strategy—absorbs £10,037,358.04. This exceeds the entire Leisure & Culture budget of £7,941,880.31 by £2,095,477.73. Residents might question whether corporate governance and executive functions should outrank libraries, parks, museums, and cultural programmes by such a margin, particularly when the latter constitutes the council's smallest named departmental spend at just 2.2% of the total.
